The code in the JSP page is pretty easy now. What we have is simply a placeholder for the table. In this example it is the ${presidents} el expression. Make sure you have the jmesa.js and jmesa.css files set in your JSP page as well. For more information about how to interact with the table see the [Javascript javascript] page. This will also describe more detail on how to use AJAX to work with the table if you choose to use that.

{{{
<html>

<head>
    <title>JMesa Example</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="${pageContext.request.contextPath}/css/jmesa.css"></link>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="${pageContext.request.contextPath}/js/jmesa.js"></script>
</head>

<body>

<form name="presidentsForm" action="${pageContext.request.contextPath}/presidents.run">
    ${presidents}
</form>

<script type="text/javascript">
function onInvokeAction(id) {
    setExportToLimit(id, '');
    createHiddenInputFieldsForLimitAndSubmit(id);
}
function onInvokeExportAction(id) {
    var parameterString = createParameterStringForLimit(id);
    location.href = '${pageContext.request.contextPath}/presidents.run?' + parameterString;
}
</script>

</body>

</html>
}}}
